text:
SPEAKER: So now you are in
multiple markets in the Gulf
and elsewhere.

How different is
the luxury consumer
in different Gulf markets?

Because one could say one tends
to have an image that the Gulf
is the Gulf and China is China.
How different are these?

PATRICK CHALHOUB: I
really love your question,
because it's absolutely true.

From the outside world, we only
say it's just a Gulf customer,

and they would act
and interact the same.
And in fact, it's not true.

It's not only by nationality,
but nationality could play.

What we notice is, one,
the different level

of maturity at the
different level of education
of the different population.

So if I take the
example of Kuwait,

where they had
universities much earlier

than the rest of the Gulf, where
they had women at college much

earlier than the rest
of the Gulf, even

in a conservative
society, in general,

we feel that the role of the
woman is much more present.

Her assertiveness
is much more there.

Her modernity, in spite
of the conservatives,

because sometimes
people say, it's

modern or conservative,
where in part of the world,
it could be both.

They could have certain
respect for tradition,

and at the same time, be
quite modern about it.

So what we found out
is really the state

of education and maturity
of the population

has always played a role of
differentiation between what's

happening in Kuwait, or
which has been probably
the most advanced.

Sometimes if I speak about
Saudi Arabia, the wealthiest

part of the population,
which has been quite

evolved and educated,
then what is happening
in other countries about it.

Then there is also the
contact which the population
have with the outside world.

It's true that when we speak
about a city like Dubai, which

is a very cosmopolitan city,
where 80% of the population

is a foreign population, there
is huge intercommunication

between the local population
and the expat population,

which means that
certain of the habit

would be transformed
much quicker than when
you live into an environment.

And probably, it's not much
different from the States,

if you go on the
Coast, or if you

go into the center of the
States, because of probably

of the contact with an outside
population, which is quite
different from one to one.

So really, stage of the
evolution, and education,

and also contact with
the outside world,

which has been quite
triggering the differences.

SPEAKER: And you have different
brands in different markets.
PATRICK CHALHOUB: We do.

And some brands are
successful in ones

and needs to be adapted
to some of the others.

But then, also, it's the
way we approach the brand.

So even if it is the
same brand, I mean, we
have some very funny examples.

Even in the same
strip of places,

because of the different
customer profile

we see, within 300
feet, if we see

a different profile
of customer, we

adjust the salespeople
who will be selling.

We adjust the
editing of the brand.

We adjust the
merchandising of the brand

in order to be more adequate
to the customer profile which
is there.
